The investigator's research under this grant focused on representation stability, a technique applying representation theory to problems in topology such as the shape of configuration space. When many indistinguishable particles such as photons or neutrons interact, aspects of their behavior are governed by the shape of this configuration space, which describes all possible ways the particles can be configured in space.  For example, this leads to the distinction between bosons and fermions, which explains why photons can cohere into a laser or helium-4 nuclei into a superfluid, whereas neutrons resist each other as is necessary for the stability of neutron stars. Moreover, the precise number of particles can be ignored as long as it is large, and this phenomenon provides an example of representation stability. During this project the investigator and his collaborators developed FI-modules, which provide a key tool for investigating the internal and external structure of stable sequences of representation. These have led to interesting and unexpected connections with other areas of mathematics, including commutative algebra, combinatorics, number theory, functor homology, asymptotic statistics, generic representation theory, and many others. FI-modules have also led to widespread applications of representation stability to problems originally formulated in other areas, as well as the importation of methods from those fields back into asymptotic representation theory.
